Problem:
Consider the role of a complex function \\(z(t) = x(t) + iy(t)\\), where \\(x(t)\\) and \\(y(t)\\) are real functions representing the position of a particle in a two-dimensional space. This function is subjected to a transformation using a Fourier transform, defined by \\( F(z)(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} z(t)e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\). We study the impact of this transformation and potential interventions on the system.

If an intervention is applied via another transformation, \\( H(z)(\\omega) = F(z)(\\omega) + K \\), with a constant \\( K \\), will the resultant Fourier spectrum still allow for the reconstruction of the original function \\( z(t) \\)?
Explanation: The addition of a constant \\( K \\) to the Fourier transform alters the spectrum and consequently affects the ability to accurately reconstruct \\( z(t) \\) from the modified Fourier transform \\( H(z)(\\omega) \\). The nature and magnitude of \\( K \\) can influence different frequencies differently, leading to inaccuracies or ambiguities in reconstructing the original function.
